frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students are given a glass block that has been treated so that the path of a beam of light can be seen as the beam travels in the glass. They are asked to determine the speed of light in the glass.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine the speed of light in the glass.
(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be used to produce a linear graph, and how that graph could be analyzed to determine an experimental value of the speed of light in the glass.

In a different experiment, the students are given a converging lens. The students are asked to determine the focal length of the lens. They measure the distance <math alttext="s sub o" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>o</mi></msub></math> from the lens to an object and the distance <math alttext="s sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> from the lens to the image formed by the object on the other side of the lens. They collect the data shown in the table.

(c)

i. Indicate what measured and/or calculated quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to determine the focal length of the lens. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.

Vertical axis: __________          Horizontal axis: __________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) that can be used to determine the focal length of the lens. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units, as appropriate.
iii. Draw the best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).
(d) Using the best-fit line, calculate an experimental value for the focal length of the lens.
